data.name: Title_1_selecting safety footwear: what to look for?
data.value: Selecting safety footwear: What to look for?

data.name: Content_1_selecting safety footwear: what to look for?
data.value:
The Right Safety Shoe

The right safety shoe prevents injuries, reduces fatigue, and improves productivity.
When choosing the right model, you should consider standards, work environment, materials, and fit together.

Standards and Classes (EN ISO 20345)

Toe Cap: Mandatory – impact resistance up to 200 joules.
Classes:

  • S1: Closed heel, antistatic, energy absorption in the heel area, resistant to oil and fuel.

  • S1P: S1 + puncture-resistant midsole.

  • S2: S1 + water-resistant upper.

  • S3: S2 + puncture resistance + cleated sole (commonly used outdoors / on construction sites).

  • S4: Polymer or rubber boots, waterproof.

  • S5: S4 + puncture resistance (for wet or muddy surfaces).

Additional Markings:

  • SRC: Highest slip resistance

  • HRO: Heat resistant up to 300 °C (contact heat)

  • CI: Cold insulation

  • WR: Fully waterproof

  • ESD / Antistatic: For electronics and ATEX environments

Key Selection Criteria

Safety Features

  • Toe Cap: Steel, composite, or aluminum

  • Puncture Protection: Midsole made of steel or textile/Kevlar

  • Slip Resistance: SRC recommended

  • Water / Chemical Protection: WR / S5, nitrile sole, PVC or PU boots

  • Thermal Properties: HRO, HI / CI; midfoot protection if needed

Comfort and Ergonomics

  • Fit and Last: Shoe should wrap around the foot with about 1 cm of space in front of the toes.

  • Weight: Lightweight models are beneficial for all-day use.

  • Cushioning and Midsole: PU / EVA improve comfort.

  • Breathability and Moisture Control: Mesh or leather lining, moisture-absorbing insole.

  • Ankle Support: High-cut for terrain/ladders, low-cut for warehouse or indoor use.

Ground Conditions and Work Environment

  • Oily / Wet Floors: SRC + fuel and oil resistance (FO) + water protection.

  • Construction / Outdoor Work: S3, cleated sole, puncture protection against stones.

  • Food Industry / Cleaning: S2 / S4–S5, easy to clean, white slip-resistant sole.

  • Metalworking / Workshop: HRO, S3, heat and spark resistant, leather upper.

  • Warehouse / Logistics: Lightweight composite toe cap, flexible textile midsole, SRC, ESD if required.

  • Electronics / ATEX Zones: ESD / antistatic, preferably metal-free.

Durability and Maintenance

  • Quality of the upper, stitching, and protective toe caps.

  • Signs of outsole wear and resistance to hydrolysis (PU may degrade due to environmental factors).

Material Guide and Benefits

Component Advantages Notes
Toe Cap Steel: Very robust, compact, affordable Heavier, conducts heat and cold
  Composite (Fiberglass / Carbon): Lightweight, metal-free, thermally insulating Slightly bulkier, more expensive
  Aluminum: Lighter than steel, thinner profile Detectable by metal detectors
Puncture Protection (Midsole) Steel: High puncture resistance, effective against sharp objects Heavier, may transfer cold
  Textile / Kevlar: Lightweight, flexible, covers full sole, non-metallic Slightly less resistant to very sharp nails
Upper Material Full-Grain Leather: Durable, water-repellent, easy to maintain Requires regular care
  Nubuck / Smooth Leather: More breathable and comfortable More sensitive, requires maintenance
  Microfiber: Lightweight, hygienic, chemical-resistant, vegan Less abrasion-resistant for heavy use
  Mesh / Textile: Highly breathable and lightweight Less durable on rough surfaces
Outsole PU (Polyurethane): Lightweight, good cushioning Sensitive to chemicals / hydrolysis
  TPU: High abrasion and slip resistance, performs well in cold  
  Nitrile Rubber: Heat resistant (HRO), oil resistant, robust Slightly heavier
  EVA (Midsole): Extra comfort and shock absorption Usually combined with other sole materials

Choosing the Right Size

  • Try shoes at the end of the day with your regular work socks.

  • About 1 cm of space in front of the toes; heel should not slip.

  • Flex point should align with the ball of the foot.

  • Try insoles with arch support if needed.

  • Models with women-specific lasts often provide a better fit.

Care, Hygiene, and Lifespan

  • Remove dirt and chemicals daily; air dry naturally (avoid heaters).

  • Ventilate insoles; alternate between two pairs to reduce odor and wear.

  • Replace shoes after impact or puncture — even if no visible damage.

  • Average lifespan depending on use: 6–24 months.

Quick Selection Guide

  • Construction / Outdoor: S3, SRC, composite toe + textile midsole, water resistant.

  • Food / Wet Areas: S2 / S4–S5, SRC, microfiber upper, easy to clean.

  • Hot Surfaces / Metalwork: S3, HRO, nitrile sole, leather upper.

  • Warehouse / Logistics: S1P / S3, lightweight, add ESD if needed.

  • Electronics / ATEX: ESD, metal-free, SRC.
